description: From Middle English caitif, from Anglo-Norman caitif (“captive”), akin to Old French chaitif (French chétif) and Middle Dutch keytyf, from a Vulgar Latin alteration of Latin captīvus (“captive”); compare Italian cattivo (“bad, wicked”). Doublet of captive.

adjectives.description: caitiff (comparative more caitiff, superlative most caitiff)

examples:
Commingled are they with that caitiff choir
Of Angels, who have not rebellious been,
Nor faithful were to God, but were for self.

entries.meaning: A base or despicable person; a wretch
examples: ‘There are plenty of Huns who have defected to the Romans, seeking gold and a quiet life. One of my first tasks as paramount chief is to bring those caitiffs back and crucify them.’

entries.meaning: (obsolete) A captive or prisoner, particularly a galley slave
(archaic) A villain, a coward or wretch
